454 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Independent - Daily Edition


July 7, 2017 Friday  
First Edition


Toddlers and babies forced to sleep rough in France as refugees remain set on UK


BYLINE: MAY BULMAN


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 23


LENGTH: 783 words


Toddlers and babies are sleeping rough in northern France, volunteers say, amid warnings that scores of destitute refugee families have returned or arrived in the area since the demolition of the "Jungle" camp last year. Photographs provided to The Independent by charities working on the ground in Dunkirk show babies less than a year old sleeping and crawling around in the woodland of one of a number of unofficial camps that have sprung up in the region.

Around 20 infants are said to be in the camp, which reportedly accommodates between 300 and 500 people, many of them whole families including grandparents and pregnant mothers. Most were former residents of the the Jungle camp in Calais and the Grande-Synthe camp in Dunkirk, both of which have been demolished in the past nine months. 

The unofficial camp photographed, which is said to have grown considerably in recent months, is dismantled by police on a weekly basis to prevent it becoming more permanent - a process which sometimes sees children get hurt, according to volunteers. In one case a three-year-old was reportedly seen with bruised face - allegedly caused by a baton while on another occasion, a mother was said to have told police that her baby was sleeping in a tent, only for officers to proceed to pepper spray the occupants.

Volunteers said there were between 40 and 50 young children in the camp, which contains no proper toilets and relies on donations from volunteers for tents, food and adequate clothing. Heather Young, a volunteer with Paris Refugee Ground Support who was in the camp photographed earlier this week, said she saw "dozens" of babies and toddlers living in the woodland along with their families.

"There are dozens of young children, around 20 babies and toddlers, sleeping rough. There are also pregnant women and grandparents sleeping in tents," she told The Independent.

"It's horrific, unbearable. How anyone can live in woods pregnant? How do you have a one-month-old baby in a tent? How do you manage that?"

Paris Refugee Ground Support's Ms Young, who has been working with refugees in France since last year, said the families in the unofficial camps tended to be the same ones "again and again", although there is also a number of new arrivals.

Following the fire in the Grande-Synthe camp in April, families were temporarily held in local sports halls, and then bussed out to accommodation centres across France.

Many have since returned to the region with hopes of getting to the UK following a "hostile" reception from French authorities, volunteers said.

Isis Mera, founder of grassroots organisation Help4Refugee Children, who took the photographs, said the refugees had become "much more visible" in Calais and Dunkirk in the past few months.

She said "abuse and antagonism" by authorities towards refugees across France was driving them back to the northern region to pursue dangerous journeys to the UK.

Ms Mera added that one family living in the woodland - a husband and wife with an eight-month-old daughter - are intent on reaching the UK illegally after being "abused racially" in France.

They had been moved to an accommodation centre after the demolition of the Jungle where the mother and baby had to share a bathroom with men. There, Ms Mera said, they received abuse and antagonism from local people. For this reason, they decided to return. Ms Young added that while previously, following the demolition of the two main camps, refugees had remained largely "hidden", the numbers are now growing so quickly that people are becoming far more visible.

"Some remain hidden in the unofficial camps, but others are just sitting in the road. There are so many people now. How can you remain constantly hidden?" she said.

"Unless the French and British authorities find a viable solution, this will just continue and get worse again. These people are resilient. They're used to it now. It's horrific that you get used to that."

It comes as a report by charity Help Refuges seen exclusively by The Independent reveals that due to the current policies implemented by the French authorities that result in an unwelcoming environment in Calais, children face significant risk to their health and safety.

These risks are exacerbated by a lack of shelter, food insecurity, lack of personal hygiene, lack of safety and a lack of community, social security and a sense of normality - the report warns that children are being failed by both the French and UK authorities.

When approached for comment, a spokesperson for the Nord-Pas-de-Calais region told The Independent: "In the context of child welfare, shelter is systematically offered to minors in connection with the organisation France Terre d'Asile."


LOAD-DATE: July 6, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: IA

455 of 500 DOCUMENTS




standard.co.uk


December 8, 2017 Friday 9:42 AM GMT 


How breaking bread helps refugees rebuild their lives


BYLINE: Susannah Butter


SECTION: COMMENT; Version:1


LENGTH: 767 words


In a refreshing change from the festive season's usual roster of drinks parties with the same friends, on Tuesday night I had dinner at Second Home's Spitalfields co-working space with a group of strangers. At the event, hosted by Help Refugees and Welcome Kitchen, hackers and other staff from the tech start-ups based there gathered for dinner with refugees. Chefs who have recently moved here from camps in Calais made a feast and the idea was to sit down together and meet new people.

Many of the refugees' first experiences of London have been detention centres and aggressive interrogations so this was a positive contrast, with jokes about learning the British art of queuing as we lined up at the buffet to pile our plates with Libyan stew and harissa that even the chef admitted was powerfully spicy. 

It's open to anyone - it's free for refugees, £40 for guests - and at past events connections have been made that have transformed lives. A London architect met a man who used to be an architect in Syria and gave him work, while another Syrian man told me he was cast in Bohemian Rhapsody, the new film about Queen, through friends he met at Welcome Kitchen and added on Facebook (Facebook is an indispensable resource for refugees building networks from scratch in a foreign country).

When I went to Calais last year, the makeshift restaurants were hives of activity. People who had lost everything found a welcome distraction in cooking, taking pride in recreating national dishes and caring for new friends by feeding them. A HelpRefugees volunteer, wearing a Choose Love T-shirt designed by Katharine Hamnett, told me she was in Calais last week - this time of year is hard, she said, with around a thousand people living there, including boys as young as nine and clashes with police trying to move illegal camps. Those who escaped are trying to learn English and build new lives. Sharing a meal feels like the place to start.

Pop phenomenon to people's poet? Just let it go, Taylor

It looks like Taylor Swift has been watching Frozen. Her new poem, written to accompany her first British Vogue cover, sounds like it's been inspired by the Disney film's anthem Let it Go. According to Swift's poem, The Trick to Holding On, you need to "let go". Apart from when it's something you should hold on to - keep up.

A poet friend called Swift's efforts "mindfulness masquerading as poetry". In her role as pop star turned guru, Swift advises guarding "your blazing self-respect", an idea that will chime across the confidence-obsessed Instagram accounts of Generation Y. Confusingly, she also refers to "phone numbers you know by heart"; surely that's all been outsourced to smartphones now?

Another poet was more charitable. He approved of the "hedge-maze life" metaphor (he wondered whether Swift meant she was the hedge and, if so, how can she escape it? Nightmare) and detected the influence of Emily Dickinson's ballad After great pain, a formal feeling comes, which also ends with "letting go". This friend is better read than I am.

Swift, who prizes control over her public image, wrote the poem instead of doing an interview. Do journalists really have such a bad reputation that it's preferable to trot out a poem? Next time, T Swift, I'd be happy to talk it out of you.

Momentum, the great party killer

The hard Left is putting a dampener on Christmas parties. There's no vibe killer like someone you considered to be a like-minded friend assuming that everyone backs Momentum's takeover of Haringey council. We had it with Brexit - some families are still not on speaking terms because of feuds around EU tariffs - and now London is riven again.

Tenacious types refuse to let debate be stifled. They incorporate swotting up on political blogs into their getting-ready-for-parties routine to arrive armed with informed arguments. They don't mind if they're cast out from WhatsApp groups, because they stood up for their beliefs. The less brave have had to become adept at changing the subject; asking Momentum mates what they make of animojis usually does the trick.

Go easy on that advent calendar

I've already seen off two advent calendars. At least I shared them, unlike a friend who hacks advent by opening up the whole calendar box to devour in one swoop. Whatever happened to edging it, eking out the pleasure of one chocolate each day? At the risk of sounding old, the advent calendars of my childhood were sugar-free - behind each window was an illustration telling the nativity story, and that was enough of a thrill. Somewhere along the line, instant gratification has replaced self-control.


LOAD-DATE: December 8, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBES

BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


November 14, 2017 Tuesday


German agencies identify three Islamist categories


LENGTH: 1040 words


Excerpt from report by right-of-centre German newspaper Die Welt website on 10 November

[Report by Florian Flade: "Frustrated, Traumatised, Radicalised." First paragraph is a Die Welt introduction.]

The security agencies constantly receive leads pointing to alleged terrorists among refugees. Three groups are of particular interest to investigators.

[passage omitted] 

A particularly disturbing situation, in the view of the security agencies: Those arriving as refugees have been shown to include not merely the victims of civil wars, but also perpetrators, such as Islamist terrorists - albeit in extremely small numbers. Identifying them is now proving to be a veritably Sisyphean task, which is likely to keep the police and intelligence services busy for many years yet. The Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution [homeland intelligence agency] now has a working group bearing the name of "Keto," responsible for systematically dealing with the issue.

Over the past few years, the constitutional protection service has received more than 2,000 leads regarding the presence of jihadists among refugees. Many of these tip-offs come from other refugees, and often amount to denunciations, or else deliberate smears. A case in point was the vilification, motivated by frustration and rage, of a fellow-resident in an asylum-seekers' hostel, as a fighter for the "Islamic State" ["of Iraq and the Levant"] terrorist militia. Such defamations are said to have become rarer recently. Though the vast majority of tip-offs continue to derive from other refugees, the information is now far less "valuable," as constitutional protection service officials put it.

Three risk groups form the prime focus of the investigators' attention. The first group consists of extremists, infiltrated into Europe under the guise of refugees from civil wars, and tasked with the specific mission of carrying out attacks here, such as those perpetrated in Paris and Brussels. The precise number of jihadists actually smuggled into Europe in this way by IS is unclear. Around 20 of such "sleepers" are thought to have already been unmasked, according to security sources.

Right now, three young Syrians are on trial in Hamburg; according to the indictment, they were sent to Germany, and entered the country equipped with forged passports and a large quantity of cash. Installed on their cellphones were encrypted instant messaging programmes, allegedly enabling them to communicate with their IS handlers. In addition, a jihadist behind bars in Lebanon claims to have seen at least one of the Syrians in an IS bolthole for suicide bombers in Syria.

As part of its "Galaxy" investigation, the Federal Criminal Police Office (BKA) has spent months examining the case against the three refugees, who were sheltered in the state of Schleswig-Holstein. They devoted hours of surveillance to them, prior to arresting the three in September 2016. Up to now, though actual evidence that the three were indeed planning to carry out an attack remains lacking. It is still no more than a hunch on the investigators' part.

The second group preoccupying the security agencies and the judiciary consists of those refugees who were active as jihadists before they came to Germany. In other words, they have a terrorist past. Though they are not necessarily regarded as posing a danger, this country's authorities do also prosecute these ex-terrorists on account of their criminal actions in the past, on charges up to and including war crimes. A wide range of investigative processes are now being devoted to such jihadist veterans, who purport to be innocent victims of war on entering Germany. or when their asylum applications are examined.

One such case is Abdul Beset al-O., who was arrested in Wuppertal in November 2016. His terror resume was revealed purely by chance. In November 2016, an Iraqi woman mentioned her violent husband in the course of her asylum application proceedings in Moenchengladbach. He beat her and ill-treated her extremely viciously, she reported. By the way, he had also been the commander of the IS terror militia, she added. The authorities promptly arranged accommodation for her in a women's refuge, and began to target her husband, who was living in Wuppertal. Iraqi Abdul Beset al-O. had entered Germany at the beginning of 2016, and had then applied for asylum. The investigations by the Federal and State Criminal Police Offices in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia revealed that Al-O. had apparently been the leader of a ten-man IS unit in Iraq, which had planned killings and abductions. According to a secret assessment by the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, Al-O. had even been trained for the purpose of "perpetration of an attack in Germany." Without the tip-off from his former wife, the Iraqi would probably not have been discovered.

The third group primarily comprises young refugees, who originally lacked any link to terrorism, but who became radicalised in Germany. This often happened in a very short time, for example through contacts that they made in Islamist mosque congregations, via contacts on social networks, or through extremist hate preachers. Riaz A., a 17-year old Afghan who attacked several people with an axe on a regional train in the state of Bavaria in July 2016, is an example of this category. Another is a 16-year old Syrian, whom investigators arrested in a refugee hostel in Cologne in September 2016. He had procured bottles of butane gas, batteries, and sewing needles, probably for the purpose of manufacturing an explosive device. An investigator later testified in court that the young man had become "turboradicalised" within a space of three months: A state of affairs which state protection agencies find disturbing, with an eye to the future. "The danger arises that young people who have failed to find any connection or foothold here will drift into extremism," warns a state protection officer. The traumatization and the psychological problems of many young refugees need to be addressed more intensively, he warns, adding that: "Frustration can very rapidly turn into hatred. And then things can get dangerous."

Source: Die Welt website in German 10 Nov 17

Press Association Mediapoint


September 6, 2017 Wednesday 4:25 PM BST 


CHILD REFUGEES AT RISK IF NOT REUNITED WITH FAMILY IN UK AFTER BREXIT, MPS WARN


BYLINE: Arj Singh, Press Association Political Correspondent


SECTION: HOME NEWS


LENGTH: 687 words


Ministers must maintain lone child refugees' right to be reunited with extended family in Britain after Brexit or they could be left stranded abroad at greater risk of sexual abuse and trafficking, MPs have warned.

They spoke after leaked Government proposals for post-Brexit immigration policy said the European Union rules will no longer apply after Brexit.

The ``Dublin III'' regulations go further than UK law as they allow children fleeing war and persecution to be reunited with grandparents, uncles and aunts, siblings, and other family members, as opposed to just their parents. 

The Home Office document, leaked to The Guardian, confirmed that the rules as they currently apply to the UK ``will not continue'' but said ministers were ``ready to discuss'' responsibility for asylum claims with Brussels.

Liberal Democrat former minister Norman Lamb said children who are alone in Europe would be at greater risk of exploitation unless the Government commits to continuing the scheme.

Mr Lamb also urged the Government to go further and extend the rights globally.

He was backed by Labour MP Andy Slaughter, who said this would help bring down the number of child refugees making dangerous and sometimes fatal journeys to EU countries to gain the right to reunification.

Their call follows claims that the Government has let down child refugees by closing the Dubs scheme, which required the UK to resettle an unspecified number of unaccompanied minors from Europe, after 480 were brought to the UK - well below the 3,000 campaigners had demanded.

While the Dublin III process has faced criticism for being too slow, Mr Lamb said it was important to get the legal position right for child refugees.

He told the Press Association: ``If you've got an orphan, someone whose parents who have both died in conflict, who is stuck in Calais or whatever, and there's an uncle and aunt living somewhere in the UK, Dublin III covers them, but the UK's own immigration rules don't.

``I want to see a commitment to maintain the rights that those children currently have.

``I don't think there can be any possible justification for reducing the rights of unaccompanied children given all of the dangers that they face.

``And I think that the inevitable consequence of a diminution of their rights is a great likelihood of exploitation, sexual abuse, violence, and everything else.

``There's a clear and stark choice for the Government here and I hope very much that they do the right thing.''

Mr Slaughter said extending these rights across the world would help save children's lives and cut down on dangerous trafficking across the Mediterranean, a stated Government aim.

``If you are in Libya or Turkey or wherever then you can't (get the right to reunification), therefore you get kids losing their lives crossing the Mediterranean which the Government says it doesn't want to happen,'' he said.

But Mr Slaughter said he thought it was unlikely that the Government would back the idea, given the ``punitive'' nature of the leaked immigration proposals, which ministers have stressed have not been finalised.

The Labour MP said: ``Clearly, from what came out this morning the line is going to be very tough in terms of - they're not giving way even on things like students or necessarily foreign workers.

``So the idea that they're actually going to change the laws to make it essentially a broader group of people getting asylum and refugee status seems to me bizarre.''

Lily Caprani, of Unicef UK, said: ``The UK will need a new set of rules for refugee family reunion as it exits the EU.

``It's critical that Brexit doesn't put at risk the ability of children fleeing war and persecution to reach the safety of their close family in the UK.

``Now is the time for the UK Government to broaden its own rules and ensure the protection of unaccompanied refugee children.

``This means simply widening the definition of family to allow children to be reunited with siblings, grandparents, aunts and uncles, as well as their parents.

``This will not take complex negotiations with the EU, it's simply a matter of the Home Office changing its own rules.''


LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire



Copyright 2017 The Press Association Limited
All Rights Reserved


458 of 500 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


September 11, 2017 Monday 2:49 AM GMT 


Greens demand Australia take 20,000 Rohingya Muslim refugees from Myanmar 'immediately' - as 300,000 flee violence in their homeland


BYLINE: STEPHEN JOHNSON FOR DAILY MAIL AUSTRALIA and AGENCE FRANCE PRESSE


SECTION: NEWS; Version:2


LENGTH: 539 words



  • •

    The Greens want Australia to accept 20,000 Muslim refugees from Myanmar 

  • •

    It comes as 300,000 Rohingyas flee Myanmar for Bangladesh since August 25 

  • •

    Greens leader Richard Di Natale has written to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull 

 

The Greens are demanding Australia immediately accept 20,000 Muslim refugees from Myanmar as the violent humanitarian crisis worsens.

Party leader Richard Di Natale has written to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull insisting Australia issue emergency humanitarian visas.

His call comes as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates 300,000 ethnic minority Rohingyas have fled Myanmar since a military crackdown began on August 25.

'I have written to the prime minister over the crisis in Myanmar and the unprecedented levels of forcible displacement we are seeing,' he told his 71,700 Facebook followers on Monday.

'We need 20,000 permanent humanitarian visas for Rohingya refugees this year and $150 million in emergency funding for the UNHCR.'

The $150 million the Greens are requesting well exceeds the $5 million the Australian government has committed so far to the Rohingya humanitarian crisis.

Foreign Minister Julie Bishop has urged Myanmar to show 'restraint' and protect civilian life as thousands of Rohingyas flee the country via the western Rakhine state into Bangladesh, a majority Muslim nation. 

The UN estimates 300,000 Rohingya refugees have arrived in neighbouring Bangladesh since Rohingya militant attacks on Myanmar security forces sparked a major military backlash. 

The 57-state Organisation of Islamic Cooperation has condemned Myanmar for 'systematic brutal acts' against its Muslim Rohingya minority and asked it to accept international UN monitors, following a summit in Kazakhstan's capital Astana.

They expressed 'serious concern about recent systematic brutal acts committed by the armed forces against the Muslim community of Rohingya in Myanmar.'

It urged Myanmar to accept UN monitors to carry out 'a thorough and independent investigation of all established violations of international human rights.. and bring those responsible to justice'.

Millions of Muslims around the world are posting Facebook message with the phrase: 'Stop Killing Muslims in Burma.' 

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the existing head of the OIC, has been a vocal critic of Myanmar and its de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi's policies against the Rohingya.

The Rohingya are reviled in Myanmar, where the roughly one million-strong community are accused of being illegal immigrants from Bangladesh.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani and Afghan leader Ashraf Ghani were among the other heads of state who attended the summit hosted by Kazakhstan and the Central Asian country's veteran autocrat Nursultan Nazarbayev.

The plight of the Rohingya has triggered broad international condemnation of Myanmar and Ms Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize winner and democracy activist who spent almost two decades under house arrest.

The Greens' call for Australia to accept 20,000 Rohingyas refugees comes two years after former prime minister Tony Abbott accepted 12,000 Syrian refugees fleeing the brutal dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad, shortly before Malcolm Turnbull rolled  him in a Liberal Party leadership coup. 


LOAD-DATE: September 11, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM



Copyright 2017 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
All Rights Reserved


459 of 500 DOCUMENTS




BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring


September 4, 2017 Monday


SPD candidate Schulz hopes to "turn around" German election


LENGTH: 2181 words


Excerpt from report by electronic edition of popular German tabloid newspaper Bild on 2 September

[Interview with SPD candidate for chancellor Martin Schulz, answering questions by Bild readers; place and date not given: "I Can Still Turn Around the Election"]

With three weeks to go until the election [federal election in Germany], [SPD Social Democratic Party of Germany) candidate for chancellor] Martin Schulz answers questions from readers of [the German daily tabloid] Bild.

[passage omitted]

[Daniela H.] Mr. Schulz, why was there such a hype about you at the beginning, but then, all of a sudden, your ratings dropped sharply? 

[Schulz] This was because of the people's high expectations! At the beginning of the year, it became evident, also in polls, that the people wished for an alternative to [Federal Chancellor] Angela Merkel. And suddenly, many people saw that there was an alternative.

Since then, the SPD has suffered quite a few defeats, some were its own fault, others happened through no fault of its own, for example, the switch of a Greens deputy to the CDU [Christian Democratic Union] in Lower Saxony, which resulted in the loss of government majority. This was not my fault, but of course, it is being interpreted as negative for me. And we lost two state elections, one in North Rhine- Westphalia, which is a very, very serious defeat for the SPD. Yet, 46 per cent of the voters are still undecided. Therefore, I think that it is still possible to turn around the election.

[Bild] In other words, you are familiar with quick ups and downs. This takes us to a topical issue, the return of [former German Defence Minister] Karl- Theodor zu Guttenberg. What do you think about his political comeback?

[Schulz] It is interesting. In my view, Mr. von und zu Guttenberg has always been a dazzling and interesting person. I think that, in the current situation, it was a tactical move of [Bavarian Minister- President] Horst Seehofer to win him over in order to prevent Markus Soeder (Bavarian Finance Minister, editors' note) as successor.

[Bild] Would Guttenberg be an asset for our political landscape?

[Schulz] I do not know. There is certainly no eternal damnation in politics. This applies also to Mr. von und zu Guttenberg. Radical conservative voters will certainly regard him as an asset, a social democrat probably will not.

[Bild] Let us consider the television debate with Angela Merkel on Sunday [3 September]. How nervous are you?

[Schulz] I am not nervous at all. It will be the first, and unfortunately also the only occasion for me and the current Federal Chancellor to meet for a debate. Angela Merkel is avoiding this, and she tried to dictate conditions that are more favourable for her. But I am not nervous.

[Bild] Can you attack Angela Merkel by focusing on the refugee issue? After all, this is a topic of major interest to our readers.

[Schulz] Refugee policy is and will remain an important issue. Just remember, all the time, I pointed out the importance of the refugee issue over and over again. I travelled to Italy to see for myself, and I was fiercely criticized for this from the CDU, which is a sign that they have no kind of master plan.

Ms. Merkel is now occupying herself with the issue again, which, in my opinion, she should have done earlier. In an interview with [the German Sunday paper] Bild am Sonntag, she said that, today, she would do everything the same way as she did in 2015. I think that there is one mistake that Ms. Merkel made in 2015, which she should not repeat, namely, not integrating the European partners beforehand, but informing them only afterward, which until today allows Poland and Hungary to shirk responsibility, justifying their behaviour by saying that they were not asked; hence, it was none of their business; it was a German problem. By the way, [Hungarian Prime Minister] Victor Orban, a good friend of Mr. Seehofer, is even asking money for the border fence that he is erecting right now. That is a bit thick.

[Bild] Let us ask once again: in concrete terms, what would you do as a chancellor if we were once again faced with a similar refugee stream as that in 2015? Would you keep the borders open, as Angela Merkel did, or would you close them?

[Schulz] Above all, I would do one thing: I would tell the European partners that Germany, Italy, and Greece alone can admit all refugees. Either the refugees are distributed in solidarity among all member countries, or Germany will call the EU budget into question. It is unacceptable to finance people who sit back at home and raise their arm against Germany.

[Bild] It will probably be the so-called "ordinary" people who have to integrate the refugees in their residential areas, their schools, and their perhaps low-skilled job environments. Can you understand that these people are afraid of losing something?

[Schulz] Of course, I perfectly understand them. This is why the distribution of refugees is a task for society as a whole. We cannot simply say, "We will manage!" and not provide the necessary funds to the people who actually do the job. By the way, what was accomplished in Germany is not the achievement of the Federal Chancellor, but that of hundreds of thousands of people who helped, apart from their job, apart from their families.

[Bild] But what would you do in concrete terms to take away the people's feeling, whether justified or not, of losing something because the government is doing so much for the refugees?

[Schulz] First of all, I would not make such an assertion because, very often, it is not true. The people have this feeling, but in reality, they will not lose anything. The best way to control such feelings is, first, to openly discuss them and, second, not to burden even more the quarters that already carry the major burden.

To be sure, it is nice to live in an exclusive residential area, mulling over the need to change the world. If no refugees arrive, all the better. But in large conurbations, where cheap apartments are requisitioned to accommodate refugees, tensions will rise. Therefore, I think that integration has also to do with involving the entire society.

[passage omitted]

[Manfred Frings] You often speak about social equality. Where is it? Just look at the young people. Who should pay their pensions?

[Schulz] Mr. Frings is absolutely right. This is precisely the biggest difference between Ms. Merkel and me in domestic policy: Ms. Merkel says that there is no need to intervene in the pension system. I have a completely different view. It is a major challenge to do something for the generation of Mr. Fring's children and grandchildren. If we do not intervene, the pension level will drop and the contributions will rise. At this point, the CDU says: well, then you need to work until age 70. This is unacceptable. We will change this.

[Bild] However, it is not quite alright to consider only the statutory pension. Most retired people have additional incomes, which can be seen from the high household incomes.

[Schulz] But this is not true for many women who worked in part-time jobs. This is not true for many single parents. And this is certainly not true for the low-wage sector, which has grown in the past few years. These people will retire someday, and then, we will have the problem of old-age poverty, especially of women. Therefore it is urgently necessary to intervene here.

[Bild] Your SPD pension concept says that the pension level should be kept at 48 per cent of the average wage and that it should not be lowered to 43 per cent. A study says that this will be detrimental to young people born 1995 and later.

[Schulz] But this is not true. It will not be detrimental to them. We want to stabilise the contribution rate until the middle of the coming decade before it will start to rise moderately. Above all, we want to stabilise the pension entry age at 67. In addition, I would like to point out that we want to conclude the new intergenerational contract in the next legislative period because we need to discuss two fundamental questions that have not been considered at all in this study.

First, can we integrate additional groups of people as contributors to the pension insurance scheme, for example solo self-employed, whose number is growing, and who have no retirement security at all? Second point: is it possible to reduce the burden on the so-called extraneous insurance benefits? Just take, for example, the mothers' pension. I am a strong advocate of the mothers' pension, but no contributions have been paid into the insurance scheme for this. Hence, it is a task for society as a whole. And the question is whether this needs to be financed from taxes.

[Bild] Do these political debates not unnecessarily fuel uncertainty among pensioners, who are really not poor at present?

[Schulz] This is Merkel's way of avoiding discussions so as not to upset people. By not addressing issues, but delaying them until kingdom come, you will not upset the people, that is true, but someday, you will drive them into a very difficult situation.

Let me tell you what the idea of the CDU is: pensions are decreasing? OK, that is a fact. The contributions are rising? OK, that is a fact; anyway, this is the legal situation. Well, we will have to work until age 70. Then, a young geriatric nurse in her early 40s, for example, will be part of the generation that has to pay higher and higher contributions, but in the end, she will receive the lowest pension in history. And on top of that, at the age of 70, she will have to nurse an 80-year-old patient. We will not support this kind of pension concept.

[passage omitted]

[Bild] Are you in favour of a policy of detente towards Russia and a better relationship with [Russian President] Putin?

[Schulz] Yes I am. But it always takes two to achieve a peaceful reconciliation. We cannot ignore the fact that the government of Putin pursues an expansive policy, a partially very aggressive foreign policy. I think that the United Nations is and will remain key to secure peace in the world. Veto-holding members of the UN Security Council have a special duty to contribute to world peace. The annexation of the Crimea peninsula by the Russian Federation, a veto-holding nation, was a massive breach of international law.

In Syria, there are incidents that are absolutely unacceptable, but a Security Council member is responsible for them. What I want to say is that I am in favour of seeking compromise with Russia. But I am also in favour of talking straight with Russia. I think that we should make offers to Russia. But this only makes sense if Russia is willing to accept them.

[Bild] We noticed that, on Twitter, you mostly, actually exclusively, criticise US President Donald Trump, but never Vladimir Putin. Why is that so, considering the sharp words you have just said?

[Schulz] This is not true. I also criticise Vladimir Putin, perhaps not on Twitter. But as a long-serving observer of the Brussels scene, you will know that, when I was President of the European Parliament, I reduced the access of the Russian Embassy staff to the European Parliament - to the Ambassador and his assistant - which, by the way, Russia described as a breach of international diplomacy.

[Bild] You said that, as a chancellor, you would try to make offers but at the same time adopt a very harsh position. This reminds us of a time when people said: we make an offer to the Soviet Union, but we also take measures to deter the regime. Is it necessary again to play a double game?

[Schulz] What we certainly do not need is a unilateral arms race that is spiralling upward, as Donald Trump - or perhaps also Vladimir Putin - is seeking. What we, the Europeans, need is a reminiscence of the great men and women of the 1970s and 1980s, who said: both must be possible: we should not only unilaterally talk about armament, but at least also test options whether arms limitation or disarmament is possible.

[Bild] What would be your basic idea, as a chancellor, to address such an issue? Do you regard Vladimir Putin and the current Russian leadership as opponents or partners?

[Schulz] That is difficult to tell: in its current foreign policy, Russia rather acts at its discretion: sometimes as a partner, and sometimes as an opponent. There is no coherent line. They very much act on the discretionary principle: if it is beneficial, we are partners. If it is not, we are opponents. We need to adapt to that.

After all, the problem of the Europeans is that we do not have a uniform line at present. And therefore, my first task as Federal Chancellor would be to gather the four G-7 countries, the United Kingdom, France - two nuclear-armed veto-holding countries - plus Italy and Germany, and to say: let us try once again, perhaps within the framework of the OSCE, to develop a joint European position in order to convince, in the end, the nuclear superpowers - the Russian Federation on the one hand, and the United States of America on the other - to join us at the negotiating table.

[passage omitted]

Source: Bild (electronic edition), Hamburg, in German 2 Sep 17

MailOnline


December 7, 2017 Thursday 2:01 PM GMT 


EU takes Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland to court for failing to take in their share of refugees


BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NEWS; Version:3


LENGTH: 582 words



  • •

    EU nations  agreed to take in 160,000 refugees from Italy and Greece in 2015 

  • •

    The three countries were to take in 10,000 in total between them 

  • •

    Hungary and Poland have taken none. The Czech Republic have taken in 12  

The European Union announced Thursday that it is taking the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland to court for failing to accommodate their fair share of refugees under a plan agreed to by the 28-country bloc two years ago. 

EU nations agreed in Sept. 2015 to relocate 160,000 refugees from Italy and Greece as the countries buckled under the arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants that year.

Under the plan, Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic were supposed to take in a combined 10,000 people. 

But Hungary and Poland have taken none at all, while the Czech Republic has accepted 12. The EU's executive Commission sought reasons why but was given no satisfactory explanations.

The Commission said Thursday that the three "remain in breach of their legal obligations" and "have given no indication that they will contribute to the implementation of the relocation decision."

Their cases are being referred to Europe's top tribunal, the Court of Justice.

The refugee relocation plan was adopted in a legally-binding vote by a majority of EU member states, but not the three refusing to take part.

The plan never worked well. As of last week, only around 32,000 refugees had been relocated in all.

The dispute has highlighted the deep divisions among Europeans over how best to handle the migrant wave, which saw more than 1 million people enter Europe in 2015, mostly from Turkey to the Greek islands and across the Mediterranean to Italy. It has also undermined trust among EU partners.

The Commission's second in command, Vice-President Frans Timmermans, said he did his utmost to avoid legal action and that the three could still do something about it as a few thousand people in the Greek islands remain eligible to be distributed.

"Going to court is always the instrument of last resort. That's not what we want," he said. "We hope we still find a way out through an act of participation by these three countries."

But Poland is intransigent. Polish Foreign Minister Witold Waszczykowski said the government was not changing its policy on migrants.

"Nothing has changed. Our position is clear: we do not agree with the solution that the European Union proposed two years ago," he told reporters Thursday.

However, the Czech Republic seemed more conciliatory, with newly appointed Prime Minister Andrej Babis told the local CTK news agency that he wants to negotiate with the Commission to get the legal action lifted.

In a separate move, the Commission also referred Hungary to the Court of Justice over two other laws, one on higher education and the other on non-governmental institutions.

In both cases, Hungary has failed to address EU concerns about the laws or amend the legislation to bring it in line with EU standards.

At the core of both laws are the Hungarian government's efforts to curtail the influence of Hungarian-American financier George Soros in Hungary.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban considers Soros a key political foe, mainly because of their diverging views on migration.

The law on nonprofits compels civic groups getting more than around $27,000 a year in funding from abroad to register themselves with a court and identify themselves as being "foreign-funded" on their websites and all publications. Many NGOs hit by the new law are partially funded by Soros.


LOAD-DATE: December 7, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM



Copyright 2017 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
All Rights Reserved


461 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


July 5, 2017 Wednesday 6:52 PM GMT 


Coroner calls for changes to treatment of child refugees after death of teenager;
Inquest into death of Mohammed Hussain, 17, hears how he was held by British officials in France before died under lorry as he tried to reach UK


BYLINE: Diane Taylor


SECTION: WORLD NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 833 words


A coroner has called for changes to the way Home Office officials in Calais and Dunkirk deal with vulnerable child refugees after a 17-year-old Kurdish refugee fled Isis in Iraq only to be crushed under the wheels of a lorry while trying to seek sanctuary in the UK.

Mohammed Hussain was detained by Home Office officials in Dunkirk for several hours last year before he concealed himself around the wheel area of a lorry heading from France to the UK. 

There have been at least three deaths of unaccompanied minors on UK soil in the last three years and at least nine children have died in France on dangerous journeys attempting to enter the UK.

Giving evidence about Home Office procedures for dealing with unaccompanied minors in northern France, Nicholas Drinkal, the director of UK Border Force with operational responsibility for Calais and Dunkirk, revealed that the UK authorities had intercepted several hundred child refugees trying to reach the UK in the last 12 months.

He told the coroner, Darren Salter, that there had been a series of shortcomings in Home Office procedures when dealing with Mohammed. These included:

· A failure to ask him if he wanted to claim asylum.

· A failure to check the lorry Mohammed smuggled himself onto.

· Errors in Home office paperwork about Mohammed that "should have been picked up".

· No signature on the paperwork to detain him, therefore he was unlawfully detained.

· No information about his rights given apart from contact details for two legal advice services, both of which had closed down several years before.

Mohammed was held in UK detention for four hours and after he was released he managed to smuggle himself onto the lorry bound for the UK. When the lorry stopped in Banbury, Oxfordshire, and reversed in the early hours of 1 April 2016, he was fatally crushed under the wheels. He had hidden himself above the lorry wheel for at least three hours enduring enormous discomfort and near freezing temperatures in the hours before his death.

The coroner identified "non-compliance with existing procedures and arguable gaps" in Home Office procedures in the controlled zone in northern France where they operate.

He said he agreed with the legal team for Mohammed's family that there was a element of "don't ask" among Home Office officials in France when dealing with unaccompanied child refugees "because this will lead to a requirement for more to be done".

He recommended that children should be provided with written information about their rights and that this information should be available in a variety of languages, that appropriate training should be given to Home Office officials in dealing with unaccompanied children and that child detention that has not been properly authorised should not happen.

Mohammed had been living in Sulaymaniyah in northern Iraq with his parents and brother when he decided to try to get to the UK. His plan was to get refugee status in the UK and then bring his parents and brother to safety. He didn't tell his parents what he was doing as he knew they would try to prevent him making the dangerous journey across Europe. Instead he told them he was going to Turkey for a visit and crossed Europe, spending six months in a refugee camp in Dunkirk.

He hoped to join his uncle Shamal Bakr Salih, a refugee living and working in a bakery in Manchester, who had undertaken to look after him. He had a right to family reunion under Dublin lll regulations but Home Office officials did not explore this with him when he was detained.

"He thought the best way to save his family was to get to the UK and then bring them here," said Salih.

"It was an appalling and traumatic experience for our family. I felt deep pain and grief for months. I still cry when I talk about him. Mohammed's family have been destroyed by what has happened."

"We as a family are also concerned about the number of children that are risking their lives in the way Mohammed did. We do not want any other unaccompanied minor to die in the way that Mohammed did. He was a good and kind boy. His body was flown back to Iraq for burial.

Drinkal said: "There are things that have come from this particular case that have changed things. Operational practices on the ground will be changing."

The coroner concluded that Mohammed died as a result of an accident. The charity Safe Passage has offered support to Mohammed's family and has launched a petition calling for family reunion rights for children like Mohammed.

George Gabriel of Safe Passage said: "As the numbers arriving in Calais start to grow again we hope this inquest will underline the urgent need for government to open this legal pathway, rather than forcing more children onto the backs of lorries and over the barbed wire onto high speed trains."

Jane Ryan, of Bhatt Murphy, the family's solicitors, said: "Mohammed's death could have been prevented. He had a right to have his application to join his uncle in the UK to have been considered under Dublin lll but this never happened."


LOAD-DATE: July 5, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2017 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


462 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


October 31, 2017 Tuesday 10:13 PM GMT 


Power shut off to final Manus compounds as 600 men refuse to leave;
Detainees say they fear for their lives in the Papua New Guinean community as Julie Bishop defends Australia's 'tough' stance


BYLINE: Helen Davidson and Calla Wahlquist


SECTION: AUSTRALIA NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 1028 words


The Manus Island detention centre has officially closed but more than 600 men are still refusing to leave, saying they fear for their lives in the Papua New Guinean community.

The UN has also supported claims by observers that community accommodation for detainees is not ready, refuting assurances given by the Australian government.

Electricity was shut off to the final compounds on Wednesday morning, more than 12 hours after the scheduled 5pm shutdown, and the generator was removed. 

Food, water and other essential services had already been stopped, and all staff left early on Tuesday.

The journalist and refugee Behrouz Boochani said detainees were keeping watch through the night, fearful of attacks by locals or attempts by authorities to forcibly remove them. They had stockpiled water in bins and some food, and obtained solar chargers for their phones.

On Wednesday afternoon, Boochani reported one detainee had self-harmed.

He said security and immigration staff had spoken with detainees and confirmed no services would be provided to them but multiple sources have also reported officials do not intend to use force to remove people today.

A refugee has harmed himself with a razor. He cut his wrist and chest. Physically he's good now but mentally is out of control- Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 1, 2017

On Wednesday Papua New Guinea's largest newspaper, the Post-Courier, declared Australia had " literally abandoned Manus Island ", sparking chaos and confusion.

Some services - like the health provider International Health and Medical Services - are expected to stay on the island but it is not known how long for or who is funding them. The PNG government has said all refugees and asylum seekers who won't settle in PNG are Australia's obligation. Australia has not responded with any clarification.

Nat Jit Lam, regional representative for the UNHCR and speaking from Lorengau, said the purpose-built community accommodation for refugees and asylum seekers was not ready.

The UNHCR had inspected two of the three units, including the newly built West Lorengau site.

"There was still major earthworks in progress," he told ABC radio. "There was heavy machinery on the ground as well, fences still being constructed.

"It doesn't look like it's ready. I'm not an expert on engineering but, as a UNHCR officer who's been working with refugees, I would not be bringing any refugees to stay there, not in that state. It's not ready at this moment."

The acting prime minister, Julie Bishop had said there was a "great deal of information" about the closure.

My response to Peter Dutton is that he is a racist, a proven liar, a fascist, and a proven human rights abuser

Nick McKim, Greens senator

"The essential services are available at the alternative accommodation - food, water, electricity, medical support," she told ABC radio on Wednesday morning. "People on Manus have had months of notice ... It makes no sense for them to stay where they are."

She would not be drawn on the PNG government's declaration that it had fullfilled its obligations and remaining detainees were Australia's responsibility.

"This is a tough policy and we are sending a very strong message that we will not tolerate people smuggling trying to get people into Australia illegally."

The Greens senator Nick McKim, who is on Manus Island, said the 600 former detainees who remain at the decommissioned immigration detention centre feared for their lives.

Detainees were told they faced "removal from an active PNG military base" if they refused to leave the detention centre but have repeatedly said they fear for their safety in the PNG community.

A report by Human Rights Watch detailed increasing violent attacks on refugees and asylum seekers, three which required medical transfers to Port Moresby or Australia.

On Tuesday there were multiple separate allegations of Manus residents looting the centre. There was also a protest outside the gates demanding that Australia take the refugees and not leave them to live in Manus.

Related: Manus Island detainees fear for safety after police squads armed 'like it's a war'

McKim told the Guardian that Dutton was "bullshitting" about the readiness of accommodation and that he had since learned there was a shortage of about 150 beds in the new units.

"So even if all the guys came out today there would be 150-plus of them who would be left on the side of the road in Lorengau, where there have been brutal attacks," he said on Wednesday.

McKim had been attempting to re-enter the detention centre but he was told to leave by immigration officials.

"They gave us five minutes' warning so I could have a bit of a chat to some of the guys through the fence," he said. "Not a lot has changed since yesterday."

He repeated claims many detainees were suffering withdrawals from the loss of psychotropic medication, which had been cut off when Australian staff left the centre, and were at risk of becoming "acutely suicidal".

On Tuesday night McKim told ABC Lateline Dutton was a liar, a racist and a "monster", after Dutton accused him of misleading detainees for his own political purpose.

"My response to Peter Dutton is that he is a racist, a proven liar, a fascist, and a proven human rights abuser," McKim said. "It's a badge of honour to be personally attacked by Peter Dutton and I'm just taking it as confirmation that I'm on the right track.

"I'm actually the one here on the ground. I've seen the photos taken yesterday of that facility and it is not ready and I'm prepared to stake my political credibility any time against the credibility of a monster like Peter Dutton."

McKim said he had not toured the new accommodation facilities himself because that would be trespassing.

The Greens leader, Richard Di Natalie, defended his senator's comments on Monday morning.

"Mr Dutton has behaved in a way that's absolutely racist, it's abhorrent," Di Natale told Radio National. "He has washed his hands of any responsibility to these people."

The Australian Council for International Development conference passed a motion on Wednesday calling on the Turnbull government to bring the men to Australia and "end their suffering".

telegraph.co.uk


September 28, 2017 Thursday 8:30 AM GMT 


Brexit must mean more, not less for child refugees


BYLINE: By Heidi Allen


SECTION: NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 651 words


This time last year, as the Calais camp was razed to the ground, the Home Secretary announced the UK would take a leading role in protecting children caught up in the demolition.

As a result, this country helped secure the transfer of over 550 unaccompanied children to their family here in the UK.

It was a welcome and compassionate step by the Home Secretary and a move only made possible by our membership of the EU's Dublin III Regulation. 

But Brexit means this legal right to safety will soon come to an end. This piece of EU legislation meant those children could reach their family; their parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles, or adult siblings.

Citizens UK welcome Refugees from "The Jungle" Calais camp as they arrive at Lunar HouseCredit: Nick Edwards

But the UK's own refugee family reunion rules do not currently recognise family in the same way, defining a refugee child's family as only their parents.

Just as Government knows Brexit must not slam the door shut on our relationship with our European neighbours, it must not close down safe and legal routes for refugee children either. 

While many people accept Brexit will mean new rules on how people come to our country, I suspect few believe it should force some of the world's most vulnerable children to make dangerous journeys with people smugglers.

Nor would they want these children to head to Calais, Dunkirk or Bilbao in order to reach the safety of their family in the UK.

Syrian children play on the slide, in East Ghouta, suburb of the capital Damascus, SyriaCredit: Sebastian Rich/UNICEF

As Unicef UK has warned, there are children still in Afghanistan whose homes are lost and embark on a long dangerous journey in search of sanctuary.

There are still children whose parents have been killed in the brutal Syrian war looking for a route out. For those children with family in the UK, family reunion is their best hope to find safety, and their best hope to find a home. 

This was recognised by David Davis, the Brexit minister, in Parliament just two weeks ago. He said: "we are a country with a strong tradition of tolerance and generosity, and if anything, I expect that to grow after we leave, not diminish."

This is the right position for us to take and a welcome statement, but so far we've seen no detail on how we intend to fill the legislative gap when we leave the EU. Children dodging shrapnel need us to build on his words. They need their family.

Children review manuals distributed by UNICEF-supported volunteers on the risks of unexploded remnants of warCredit: Sebastian Rich/UNICEF

This month Parliament started debating the EU Withdrawal Bill - the so-called Great Repeal Bill - which is set to transpose EU Regulations into UK law.

Does this mean the Dublin III Regulations will automatically become the UK's regulations? Our generosity as a nation and sense of global partner would be reaffirmed if we had clarification on this. The Immigration Bill is some way away, but the refugee crisis remains ever present.

By expanding our family reunion rules so that refugee children can apply from source countries to be with their family in the UK, managed by our own embassies and consulates, we can really start to take forward our vision for  a 'Global Britain'.

That's why Unicef UK's report today on keeping refugee families together is so important. Right now a child is trafficked or exploited every 30 minutes taking the central Mediterranean route.

If legislative clarification can stop even just a few hundred children making those unnecessary journeys, then it's a change worth making. 

Fixing this through our own rules is simple - it doesn't require complex European negotiations. It just needs a decision by the Government to extend Dublin III into our own legislation so children can escape war and reach the safety of their family. Let Brexit help them take back control of their futures too.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2017 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


464 of 500 DOCUMENTS




The Independent (United Kingdom)


September 17, 2017 Sunday 12:45 PM GMT 


Rohingya refugees 'could starve to death' in Bangladesh after fleeing violent persecution in Burma;
'The demand for food, shelter, water and basic hygiene support is not being met due to the sheer number of people in need'


BYLINE: Chris Baynes


SECTION: ASIA; Version:1


LENGTH: 774 words


Rohingya refugees fleeing violent persecution in Burma could starve to death amid a growing humanitarian crisis, an aid agency has warned.

Nearly 410,000 members of the country's Rohingya Muslim minority face shortages of food, water, and shelter after escaping from western Rakhine state into Bangladesh.

They have fled a Burmese military offensive that the United Nations has branded "a textbook example of ethnic cleansing". 

Read more

Bangladesh to build huge camps for Burma's Rohingya refugees

"Many people are arriving hungry, exhausted and with no food or water," said Mark Pierce, Bangladesh country director the Save the Childrencharity.

He added:"I'm particularly worried that the demand for food, shelter, water and basic hygiene support is not being met due to the sheer number of people in need. If families can't meet their basic needs, the suffering will get even worse and lives could be lost."

For decades Bangladesh has received influxes of Rohingya fleeing from Buddhist-majority Burma, where they are reviled by many as illegal immigrants and suffer systematicdiscrimination.

Bangladesh was already home to 400,000 Rohingya before the latest crisis erupted last month.

The country's government has committed to building thousands of shelters to house displaced people, with the United Nations Refugee Agency warning existing camps were "bursting at the seams".

Mr Pierce said the humanitarian response needed be urgently scaled up.

"That can only be done if the international community steps up funding," he added.

Rohingya

 refugees sit on the roadside as they take shelter during rain in Cox's

Bazar

, Bangladesh (Reuters)

Save the Children said more than amillionRohingyarefugeescould be in Bangladesh by the end of the year. Itestimated that figure would include 600,000 children, many "alone and in desperate need of help" and at risk of exploitation and trafficking.

Some child refugees were reported to havewitnessed the murder of their parents, the charity added.

Human rights monitors and fleeing Rohingya have said Burmese security forces and Rakhine Buddhist vigilantes launched campaign of violence and arson aimed at driving out the Muslim population.

The violence was said to be in response to attacks by

Rohingya insurgents on police posts and an army camp, which killed a dozen people on 25 August.

Burma has rejected allegations of ethnic cleansing, claiming its security forces were carrying out clearance operations to defend against the insurgents of the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army, which claimed responsibility for the August attacks and similar, smaller raids in October last year.

Read more

The EU must recognise Burma's human rights abuses and rethink trade

Bangladeshi boatmen save fellow Muslims trapped in Burma - for a price

Burma using scorched earth tactics to drive out Rohingya Muslims

The government has declared the group a terrorist organisation and accused it of lighting the fires itself and attacking civilians.

More than 430 people have been killed, most of them insurgents, and about 30,000 non-Muslim villagers have been displaced, according to the government.

Human Rights Watch said satellite imagery showed 62 Rohingya villages had been torched in an orchestrated campaign.

Amnesty International said there was evidence security forces were using scorched-earth tactics to drive out the minority.

Entire villages have been burned down by vigilante mobs and the military and people trying to flee have been shot, the organisation said.

Video footage that emerged from the country this week appeared to show the bodies of young Rohingya children washed up on the shores of the Naf river after reportedly being shot dead by police.

Rohingya

Muslims flee violence in Burma

Some 100 Rohingya are also said to have drowned trying to cross the river, which formers a natural border between Burma and Bangladesh.

Burmese government leader and Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi has faced a barrage of criticism from abroad for not doing moreto stopthe violence or condemning it more forcefully.

The military is in full control of Burma's security policy and the offensive has wide supportin a country where there is little publicsympathy for the Rohingya.

Ms Suu Kyi is due to make her first address to the nation on the crisis this week.

Her foreign supporters and Western governments that backed her campaign against military rule will be hoping to see her make a new commitment to protect the rights of the Muslim minority.

At home, her supporters could be disappointed if she is perceived to be caving in to foreign pressure and taking the side of a Muslim minority blamed for initiating the violence.


LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBI



Copyright 2017 Independent Digital News and Media Limited
All Rights Reserved


465 of 500 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


September 19, 2017 Tuesday 1:22 PM GMT 


Fact check: Seven quotes from Aung San Suu Kyi's speech that ignore the reality of the Rohingya crisis


BYLINE: By Roland Oliphant


SECTION: NEWS; Version:2


LENGTH: 1267 words


It was Aung San Suu Kyi's "last chance" to halt a humanitarian catastrophe and save her reputation as a champion of human rights. 

In her first public address since the outbreak of an apparent campaign of ethnic cleansing against Burma's Rohingya Muslim minority three weeks ago, Ms Suu Kyi on Tuesday pledged her government's commitment to universal human rights and promised diplomats access to Rakhine state to investigate the crisis. 

But critics accused her of obfuscation, misleading statements, and ultimately failing to address the grim truth - that the army she nominally controls is conducting a brutal campaign of arson, rape, and murder . 

Here are seven key lines from Ms Suu Kyi's speech that critics say will damage her reputation.  

1. '(Burma) does not fear international scrutiny'

"If you are interested in joining us in our endeavours, please let us know," Ms Suu Kyi told assembled diplomats. "We can arrange for you to visit these areas, and to ask them for yourselves why [remaining Muslim residents] have not fled."

Smoke rising from Burma seen from the Bangladeshi side of the on Thursday September 14Credit: Dar Yasin/AP

In reality, access to Rakhine state for journalists, diplomats, and aid workers has been severely restricted for months. 

Yanghee Lee, a UN special rapporteur for human rights, was denied access to parts of region for security reasons earlier this year and in June complained that official investigations into alleged military abuses were "without a robust methodology or witness protection policies."

Roland Oliphant: The scale of the Rohingya crisis 'is mindblowing' 00:56

In Late August Ms Suu Kyi's office accused aid agencies of colluding with "terrorists" - forcing several aid agencies to curtail operations in Rakhine state out of fears for the safety of their staff. 

2. 'More than 50 percent of the villages of Muslims are intact - they are as they were before the attacks took place' 

Human Rights Watch reported on Monday that it had counted 214 villages almost totally destroyed in Rakhine state since August 25. The figure, based on analysis of new satellite images, amounts to the destruction of tens of thousands of homes.  

The UN estimates at least 420,000 Rohingya refugees have fled to Bangladesh from Rakhine state in the past three weeks - nearly half of the estimated 1.1 million Rohingya who live there.

Children 'burned alive' say Rohingya refugees 01:48

The Myanmar Ministry of information claimed on Friday that 176  of 471 Rohingya villages had been abandoned and some had fled from another 34 villages.

3. 'Humanitarian aid reached all communities in 95 percent of affected areas before the recent attacks on August 25.' 

Aid workers speaking off the record say that UN and other agencies were forced to shut down all operations in Rakhine state after August 25, and the entire region was closed to relief operations.

Rohingya Muslim women stretch their arms out to collect sanitary products distributed by aid agencies near Balukhali refugee camp, BangladeshCredit: Dar Yasin/AP

Some aid agencies remain in Sittwe, the regional capital, but have been effectively confined to barracks since Ms Suu Kyi's office said in a statement that aid workers were colluding with "terrorists" three weeks ago. 

It is unclear whether access to the affected areas in the north of Rakhine state will be restored.

4. 'Since December 2016, local and foreign media groups have been given access to area previously off limits in Rakhine. Even after the outbreaks on the 25th of August we arrange for several media groups to visit the afflicted areas' 

Rakhine state is effectively closed to journalists operating independently.

Earlier in September, one small group of journalists were taken on a tightly controlled tour accompanied by government minders.

Rohingya refugees wait to be transported to Cox's Bazar after their arrival in Bangladesh on MondayCredit:  CATHAL MCNAUGHTON/ REUTERS

The BBC team on the tour reported being handed clearly faked photographs by government minders and speaking to transparently fake interviewees who claimed to have been burnt out of their homes by Rohingya militants.

One of the interviewees even showed up playing the role of a "militant" in the photographs.

5. 'Those who have been verified as refugees from this country will be accepted without any problems and with full assurance of their security and access to humanitarian aid' 

Ms Suu Kyi referred specifically to "principles" agreed between Burma and Bangladesh following a previous exodus of Rohingya refugees in 1992 - 1993.  

The 1993 agreement means refugees who can prove their residence in Burma with documents may return. But it says nothing about those who either did not possess such paperwork or were forced to flee before they were able to gather their documents.

<table>

Translation: #Rohingya who survived massacres & lost everything from massive arson attacks can return if they can prove their residency... https://t.co/eF5Khaos2Q

- Matthew Smith (@matthewfsmith) September 19, 2017

Ms Suu Kyi's promise of safe return also appears to contradict an earlier statement from Burma's information ministry which accused refugees of complicity in terrorism.

"Those who fled the villages made their way to the other country for fear of being arrested as they got involved in the violent attacks," the ministry said on Friday .

6. 'There have been no conflicts since the 5th of September and no clearance operations' 

Human rights activists and journalists, including from the The Telegraph, have interviewed dozens if not hundreds of refugees who have reported on-going violence in Rakhine state almost daily for the past three weeks.

<table>

Aung San Suu Kyi claims no military "clearance operations" in Rakhine since 5 Sept! What's this then? She's delusional. pic.twitter.com/EcSicI1XL0

- Jonathan Miller (@millerC4) September 19, 2017

And you don't have to take the refugees' word for it. Smoke from burning villages - the result of so-called "clearance operations" - has been seen from the border almost everyday.  

7. 'There have been allegations and counter allegations. And we have to listen to all of them, and we have to make sure that these allegations are based on solid evidence'

Ms Suu Kyi is right that there are contradictory allegations flying around. But there is no longer any doubt about the crimes being committed by the Burmese military.

The United Nations, foreign governments,  human rights groups, and independent journalists have reached the conclusion that the Burmese military and vigilante mobs are carrying out a campaign of arson, murder, rape, and eviction that amounts to ethnic cleansing  of the Rohingya minority.

 People hold the Myanmar national flag and placards as they listen to Aung San Suu Kyi's speech in front of City Hall in YangonCredit:  AUNG KYAW HTET/AFP

That conclusion is supported by multiple consistent accounts provided by refugees; satellite imagery; and accounts from reporters allowed into Rakhine under strict government control.

What is also undisputed is that a previously little-known insurgent group, the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army, carried out deadly attacks on Burmese security forces on August 25.

It is unclear whether the group has also carried out attacks on non-Rohingya civilians.

There is no evidence to support claims by the army that Rohingya refugees have set fire to their own villages in a bid to incriminate the authorities - a tale they have tried to support with transparently faked photographs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2017 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


466 of 500 DOCUMENTS




FinancialWire


September 29, 2017 Friday


Rohingya refugee crisis a 'human rights nightmare,' UN chief tells Security Council


LENGTH: 706 words


Noting that the humanitarian crisis that has resulted in displacement of hundreds of thousands of Rohingyas from Myanmar not only provides a "breeding ground" for radicalization, but also puts vulnerable people - including young children - at grave risk, United Nations Secretary-General called for "swift action" to prevent further instability and find a durable solution. 



"The situation has spiralled into the world's fastest developing refugee emergency and a humanitarian and human rights nightmare," Secretary-General António Guterres said today at a Security Council meeting on the situation in Myanmar.

At least 500,000 civilians have fled their homes in the country's northern Rakhine state since late August and sought refuge in Bangladesh. According to estimates, some 94 per cent among them are members of the minority Muslim Rohingya community.

There have also been reports of burning of Muslim villages, as well as looting and acts of intimidation. Authorities in Myanmar have indicated that at least 176 of 471 Muslim villages in northern Rakhine have been totally abandoned.

"We have received bone-chilling accounts from those who fled - mainly women, children and the elderly," added the UN chief, noting that testimonies pointed to serious violations of human rights, including indiscriminate firing of weapons, the presence of landmines and sexual violence.

"This is unacceptable and must end immediately."



Secretary-General António Guterres briefs the Security Council meeting on the situation in Rahkine state of Myanmar, which has seen hundreds of thousands of Rohingya refugees fleeing to neighbouring Bangladesh over the last several weeks. UN Photo/Kim Haughton Failure to address the violence could result in a spill-over into central Rakhine - where an additional 250,000 Muslims could potentially face displacement - Mr. Guterres warned, stressing that Government must ensure the safety and security of all communities and uphold rule of law without discrimination. In his briefing, the Secretary-General also underscored that UN agencies and their non-governmental partners must be granted immediate and safe access to all affected communities. Speaking also on the need to ensure safe, voluntary, dignified and sustainable return of the refugees to their areas of origin, Mr. Guterres noted that the 1993 Joint Statement of the Foreign Ministers of Bangladesh and Myanmar could be a useful starting point, but it is not sufficient in the present circumstances, in particular as it does not refer to resolving the root cause of displacement as well as because it requires documents that the refugee Rohingya may not be able to provide. "Ensuring the safe, voluntary and dignified return of refugees to Rakhine - in line with international refugee law - will require the restoration of mutual trust among the communities," he said, noting that improved inter-communal relations forms a critical part of a sustainable solution to the crisis. Mt. Guterres further noted that the issue of protracted statelessness must be resolved. "The Muslims of Rakhine state should be granted nationality," he stated, adding that while the present Myanmar citizenship legislation only allows it partially, an effective verification exercise should be conducted in the interim to allow those entitled be granted citizenship based on the present laws. "All others must be able to obtain a legal status that allows them to lead a normal life, including freedom of movement and access to labour markets, education and health services," he added. In his remarks, the UN chief also spoke of a donor conference to be convened by the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the International Organization for Migration (IOM) as well as noted efforts by regional actors to help address the crisis. "I look forward to effective and credible follow-up to the authorities' stated commitment to greater access, including for the international community, the media and humanitarian actors," he said, noting: "The regional cooperation with Myanmar will also be essential, and the United Nations fully stands behind this."



(Distributed by M2 Communications (www.m2.com))
