500 of 500 DOCUMENTS




Express Online


November 8, 2017 Wednesday 12:00 AM GMT 


Foreign aid madness: How £1.9bn from budget goes on refugee help


BYLINE: Giles Sheldrick


LENGTH: 762 words


BRITAIN will spend £1.9 billion of foreign aid cash in just five years looking after asylum seekers and refugees, figures show.

GETTY

Britain is to spend £1.9 billion of foreign aid cash on looking after asylum seekers and refugees

The amount the Home Office plans to shell out could fund 82,745 new police officers. 

It wants to maintain the current level of support given to those seeking refuge in the UK.

And it has already told the Daily Express the "majority" of the £362 million it contributes to the bloated budget each year is swallowed up supporting migrants.

But projected spending on Official Development Assistance until 2021 means taxpayers will continue to shoulder the burden of "refugee programmes", providing bed and board for tens of thousands of newcomers, many of whom have arrived here illegally. 

SIGN THE PETITION ONLINE TO STOP THE FOREIGN AID MADNESS HERE

Related articles The government needs to stop 'squandering' taxpayer money Foreign aid: Fury over 'cover-up' of how taxpayers' money

The billions of pounds of public money spent on ODA has prompted 70,000 Daily Express readers to back our Stop The Foreign Aid Madness Crusade demanding the Government urgently redirects money into struggling frontline services such as the NHS.

The UK is committed to spending 0.7 per cent of our national income on foreign aid.

Last year it cost taxpayers £13.3 billion. But cross-party concern has been raised that it is being used to support economic migrants and not those in genuine need of sanctuary.

Ukip deputy leader Margot Parker said: "For this amount of taxpayers' cash to be paying for asylum seekers almost beggars belief. The Government should stop this cavalier squandering of our cash. There is a Budget coming up - let's see some action to scale back on this spending and use the money to cure many of the problems facing the country."

GETTY

Ukip deputy leader Margot Parker said she wanted to see 'some action to scale back on this spending'

Yesterday managers of hospital and ambulance trusts across England claimed staff shortages in the overrun NHS pose a serious risk to patient safety and quality of care.

The NHS is on the cusp of a recruitment crisis with an estimated shortage of at least 50,000 doctors and nurses.

Our campaign is calling for money to be redirected into the services on which millions of people rely but which teeter on the brink of collapse.

Tory MP David Davies said: "Far too many economic migrants are trying to come to the UK simply for a better life."

He wants money spent on asylum seekers directed to refugee camps across North Africa to discourage thousands from risking their lives trying to reach Europe.

GETTY

David Davis said he wants money spent on asylum seekers directed to refugee camps

Documents show planned spending on ODA would see the Home Office fork out £1.94 billion to "maintain the current refugee programmes and provide assistance on new areas".

The department, run by Home Secretary Amber Rudd and responsible for securing our borders from illegal immigration, confirmed the lion's share of its foreign aid commitment is spent on asylum support and the Syrian Vulnerable People Resettlement Scheme.

The scheme aims to relocate 20,000 Syrian refugees from camps in Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Egypt and Turkey by 2020. Even those who have reached the UK illegally are provided with a place to live, a cash allowance or both while claims are processed.

Current rules see each individual pocket £36.95 a week with those who have been refused asylum getting £35.39 on a payment card for food, clothing and toiletries.

GETTY

The UK is committed to spending 0.7 per cent of our national income on foreign aid

Claimants also get free NHS treatment while their children are found school places and given free meals.

The Home Office said: "The UK has a long and proud history of granting asylum to those who genuinely need our protection."

It added that more than 8,500 people had been resettled so far - half of whom were children.

It said: "We also support projects to build the capacity and capability of countries to deal with border security, drug smuggling, modern slavery and child protection online.

"It is in our interest to help tackle these issues abroad so as to lessen their impact in the UK."

To sign the Daily Express petition online see below 

Related articles UK foreign aid: Brexit Britain should 'stop funding EU foreign aid' Foreign Aid madness: BBC 'spending £24 million from LICENCE FEE on ove 67,000 rush to back our crusade to end Britain's foreign aid project

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDE
